reviewText: Andrew Zimmern is such a...NUT... for "bizarre foods". He LOVES him some "nuts". "Bizarre" food they call it for the show and it IS, from our American-living-in-the-21st-Century perspective. But basically the food Zimmern consumes is traditional food from places all over the world the preparation and consumption of which dates back to before the time of freezers and refrigerators and when people couldn't afford to waste one bit of precious edible animal or plant. Not one bit. And being that food could not usually be preserved by freezing it, often it would rot and be eaten latter. This is a fun show and a good edition to the Travel Channel lineup. Zimmern will probably not convince you to broaden your pallet to the level of his or make your appetite so voracious that you'll be traveling the globe gobbling down all the nuts you can get your hands on. But it is entertaining watching him gobble down *anything* put before him and you'll have a greater awareness of almost limitless culinary possibilities. How narrow and lacking in imagination we have been! McDonald's?! Now THAT is truly bizarre food! This is surely Zimmern's mission you see. In one episode he actually meets his match. You know what it was? Well, I'm not sure myself, but it's called "stinky tofu". This little old Asian lady prepares her tofu squares by letting them soak for days in some sort of rotten juice made from vegetables. Or something. Point is it is rotten and reminds me of muddy swamp water and it's absolutely revolting. It induced Zimmern's gag reflex.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Andrew Zimmern's Bizarre Foods is really fun to watch, because he is so funny.  His shows are educational, even if they can be rather disgusting at times.Mr. Zimmern does something that no one else does, that I know of.  He actually describes the food that he is eating.  He tells viewers the taste, texture, and sometimes the smell of the food.  He will even compare the more unusual foods to something more familiar to audiences in the United States.When Amazon added the description of the set, they listed the episodes and locations included in the set.  They completely forgot to add Mexico.The only disappointing thing about this set is that they did not include subtitles.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I first started watching this show when I was a vegetarian(I am no longer) and I enjoyed it tremendously. It's not even so much about the "weird" foods, but I was just entertained by Andrew's persona and the way he enjoys these different cultures and the cuisines they offer.For this particular collection, I really loved the Moroccon and Equadorian episodes. All those sheep heads baked right out in the street, fascinating! And those yummy little Cuys which you can pick out like a lobster in a fancy seafood restaurant.My other favorite food guy, Anthony Bourdain, even makes an appearance in the New York City episode. These two should have a regular show together. Also, gotta mention those fat little worms in the Philippine episode. Poor fellas, even Zimmern didn't think they were too savory(think he prefered the ones from Equador).
Title: N/A

reviewText: Wow! I did not know, right in New York, people ate bizarre foods such as live-lobster sushi, cockroach, and maggots before watching this. This set of 2 DVDs captivatingly and lively shows the exotic foods and interesting local people all over the world.Below are some of the foods that Andrew tasted- In New York: Live-lobster sushi, cockroach, maggots, scorpions, earthworm, tarantulas, durian, etc.- In Mexico: Armadillo, grasshoppers, mosquito eggs, corn fungus, live bugs called jumiles (small stink bugs of the species Atizies taxcoensis). Yuk!- In Gulf Coast: Nutria ( a kind of large rodents)- United Kingdom: Haggis, jellied eels, tongue sausage, herring roe, etc.In short, if you love travelling and exotic foods, you don't want to miss this one.
summary: The BEST that MY MONEY can GET in terms of EXOTIC FOOD and TRAVELLING

reviewText: Andrew Zimmern is a great guy and perfect for hosting "Bizarre Foods" - he is laidback, courteous to everyone, respectful of all cultures, and has guts of steel! OMG - the food he consumes in this show just defy credibility, but consume them he does, and he seems to genuinely enjoy most of them,lol. In this collection, Andrew visits Morocco, Spain, the Philippines, Ecuador, New York City, the UK, and America's Gulf Coast. Having always had the dream of visiting Morocco someday, I have to say that was my favorite episode, but um, I think I'll refrain from trying out some of the more exotic dishes on the menu:) Great show, I love "Bizarre Foods" [and my other favorite is "No Reservations" with Anthony Bourdain].
summary: I am hopelessly addicted to this show!
